definition:
It is a standard exercise in elementary combinatorics to the number of
ways of rolling any given value with 2 fair 6-sided dice (by taking the
of the two rolls). The below table the number of such ways of rolling a
given value $n$:

  ----- ------------
   $n$   \# of ways
    2        1
    3        2
    4        3
    5        4
    6        5
    7        6
    8        5
    9        4
   10        3
   11        2
   12        1
  ----- ------------

A somewhat (un?)natural question is to ask whether or not there are any
other ways of re-labeling the faces of the dice with positive integers
that these sums with the same frequencies. The surprising answer to this
question is that there does indeed exist such a re-labeling, via the
labeling $$\begin{aligned}
\mbox{Die }1&=\{1,2,2,3,3,4\}\\
\mbox{Die }2&=\{1,3,4,5,6,8\}\\\end{aligned}$$ and a pair of dice with
this labeling are called a set of *crazy dice*. It is straight-forward
to verify that the various possible occur with the same frequencies as
given by the above table.
